description:
Pithys albifrons albifrons, commonly known as the White-fronted Antbird, is a species of antbird found in the tropical forests of South America. It is a small, round-bodied bird with a short, pointed beak and a distinctive white forehead and eyebrow stripe.

The subspecies Pithys albifrons albifrons is found in the northern part of the species' range, from eastern Colombia and southern Venezuela to the Guianas and northern Brazil. It typically inhabits the understory and mid-levels of humid, lowland and foothill forests, where it forages for small insects and other invertebrates.

This antbird is known for its social and cooperative behavior, often traveling in mixed-species flocks and participating in "ant swarms" with other ant-following birds. Its call is a series of high-pitched, metallic-sounding notes, which it uses to communicate and maintain contact within its social group.

The White-fronted Antbird is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), as it has a wide distribution and is relatively common throughout its range. However, it may be affected by habitat loss and fragmentation in some areas due to deforestation and other human activities.
